div.p:
Dear Ms. Musulin,
I have very much enjoyed reading your piece on Auden in Kirchstetten; it is lively and warm and
fascinating. We would like to publish it in Auden Studies 2, and we hope that you will be willing to make a few
changes to this end.

Most of all, the piece is a little long for us. I don't want to suggest a strict word limit because I like
the chatty anecdotal feel of it, but would it be possible to reduce the length by about 20% to 25%? I gather that the
first section was a lecture, and perhaps the opening, for a printed book, could be a bit more incisive; the
opening of the second section might also be more direct. In fact, for our purposes, it would be better if the two
sections were integrated into one, or at least dovetailed more efficiently so that any repetition in avoided. (For instance the tax problem comes up at the end of the first section but then is not gone into until quite a bit
further on in the second section.) If you cannot fully combine the two sections, you might consider making them more clearly balanced and parallel, and perhaps giving each one a date (of composition) as a subtitle.
Finally, I think you could save some space at the end by shortening the account of the funeral arrangements.

In one or two places I found myself mildly confused and wishing for clarification. First of all, we do not
seem to have page 24 of your first section. Second, in the first account of the speech given at Neulengbach I felt
unsure as to what exactly was being quoted and paraphrased from the speech - probably because I don't have a
text of the speech - perhaps you could spell this out a bit more in the piece. Third, I was unclear as to whether
the 'In Retrospect' has already been published in a volume edited by Peter Müller, you seem to suggest this in
your opening passage. We would want to be sure to give details of your PEN talk and any previous publication
in a footnote at the start of the piece, so I would be grateful if you could provide these.

With regard to footnotes, it would be helpful if you could give exact citations for everything you quote
from Auden's published works, poetry and prose. I am enclosing a copy of 'Notes to OUP Authors' which you
may find helpful in this and other matters of presentation. I hope you won't find it daunting; it's not nearly so
dull or difficult as it looks. The footnotes you have given are not far off our usual form; we normally use a
comma after the author's name, and underline titles of books and periodicals. Also, we give place of
publication, but not the name of the publisher. For most of the books you cite, we will probably use an
abbreviated form of reference, but in any case, it would be useful to have things set down properly in full. Also,
for your own letters from Auden, if any of these are dated more precisely than you already indicate, please add
further details.

You will see that I have not returned your manuscript with this letter. I would like to keep it, if you
have another copy that you can work from. If not, please let me know.

I am sorry that we have taken so long getting back to you about this. I look forward to hearing from
you when you have the opportunity.
Yours with best wishes,
